title-group.article-title: Synergistic effect of fermented raspberry juice and high hydrostatic pressure along with coconut sap in chitosan coating for barramundi preservation

abstract.p: This study aimed to investigate the biological properties of probiotic and synbiotic Lactobacillus gasseri SM 05 (L. gasseri) and Lactobacillus casei subsp. casei (L. casei) in the black raspberry (BR) matrix. A distinctive aspect of this research was its assessment of both fermented and non-fermented raspberry juices as active components in chitosan-based edible coatings, supplemented by coconut sap at concentrations of 5% and 10%, along with the application of high hydrostatic pressure (HHP) processing. These interventions were evaluated for their synergistic potential in enhancing the antioxidant capacity of coatings applied to Lates calcarifer (barramundi) fillets. What distinguishes this study from prior works is the integration of cutting-edge HHP technology, the deliberate exclusion of essential oils and synthetic preservatives, and the novel incorporation of coconut sap across coating formulations. Experimental outcomes revealed that synbiotic formulations—specifically L. gasseri combined with Oligofructose-Enriched Inulin (LG-OEI) and L. casei with OEI (LC-OEI)—exerted the most pronounced bioactivity. The key findings underscore the efficacy of Oligofructose-Enriched Inulin in promoting lactic acid bacterial metabolism and metabolite production within fruit juice substrates. Additionally, the deployment of 10% coconut sap in conjunction with HHP treatment—rather than conventional VAT pasteurization—yielded superior coating performance, effectively preserving the quality of fish samples over a 15-day period. In conclusion, the LG-OEI formulation, when used in chitosan coatings augmented with 10% coconut sap and processed via HHP, demonstrated the highest preservation efficacy.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The Rosaceae family encompasses approximately 3,000 species, with nearly 500 classified under the genus Rubus, which is extensively distributed across temperate regions worldwide1. Among these, black raspberry (BR), a prominent member of the Rubus lineage, is distinguished by its rich antioxidant profile, including phenolic acids, flavonoids, anthocyanins, quercetin, organic acids, ellagitannins, gallotannins, and triterpenoids2–5. Notably, Members of the BR family have long been incorporated into various food and pharmaceutical formulations, including ice creams, fruit juices, jams, jellies, baked goods, and medicinal products6. The application of raspberry seeds in food systems is facilitated by their favorable fatty acid composition, particularly the low n-6:n-3 ratio. Furthermore, black mulberry seed oil exhibits greater oxidative stability than raspberry seed oil, making it a more resilient option from a lipid oxidation standpoint7.

Similar to other fruits, BR contains both free phenolic compounds (PCs) and insoluble-bound phenolics (IBPs), the latter of which represent approximately half of the total phenolic content in food matrices. IBPs are covalently linked to macromolecular constituents with recognized nutritional value, such as pectin, hemicellulose, and arabinoxylan. These compounds are predominantly localized within the plant cell walls—particularly in grains, fruits, and legumes—and can be liberated through chemical (acidic, enzymatic, or alkaline) or physical (thermal and non-thermal) extraction methods8.

Fermentation (FT), high-hyrostatic pressure processing (HHP), and germination are commonly employed strategies for liberating insoluble-bound phenolics (IBPs) from diverse biological matrices. Each of these techniques promotes the disruption of covalent linkages between IBPs and plant cell wall polymers, thereby enhancing their bioaccessibility and potential health benefits9. Fermentation (FT) utilizing lactic acid (LA) bacteria represents one of the most ancient and enduring food preservation techniques. This method has demonstrated considerable efficacy in enhancing the nutritional quality, organoleptic attributes, and overall health-promoting potential of various food products10. Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) play a significant role in promoting human health through diverse biological mechanisms, one of which involves the enhancement of PC bioavailability. Among these, Lactobacillus plantarum is particularly notable for its enzymatic capacity to metabolize PCs via key catalytic activities, including those of decarboxylase, dehydrogenase, tannase, reductase, and esterase. These enzymatic pathways contribute to the structural transformation and increased bioactivity of PC, potentially amplifying their antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects11.

Lactobacillus gasseri is considered a beneficial lactic acid bacterium due to its diverse health-promoting properties. Prolonged administration of a specific strain, L. gasseri CP2305, has been shown to positively influence cognitive function, sleep quality, and intestinal microbiota composition under conditions of psychological stress12. Moreover, this strain exhibits satisfactory adhesion to human epithelial cell models, including Caco-2 and vaginal VK2 cell lines13. suggesting its potential for colonization and functionality in host tissues. Another well-studied lactic acid bacterium is Lactobacillus casei. In a 2010 study, the antioxidant activity of L. casei subsp. casei was evaluated in an aged murine model. Oral administration of live cells at moderate to high doses (10–20 mL/kg) significantly reduced malondialdehyde levels in both serum and liver tissue, indicating a mitigation of oxidative stress and potential for age-related health improvement14. Furthermore, administration of live Lactobacillus casei cells was shown to significantly enhance glutathione peroxidase activity and elevate total antioxidant capacity in aged murine models. These findings suggest a pronounced improvement in cellular antioxidant defenses, thereby indicating the bacterium’s potential anti-aging properties through attenuation of oxidative stress14. In addition to the aforementioned FT technique, HHP represents a pivotal non-thermal approach for the preservation of PCs. This method is widely recognized for its capacity to enhance food safety and extend shelf life, while exerting minimal influence on the sensory and physicochemical attributes of food products. By circumventing the thermal degradation pathways typically associated with conventional heat-based treatments, HHP offers a promising alternative for maintaining the integrity and bioactivity of PCs in various food matrices15. A key advantage of HHP is its ability to inactivate pathogenic microorganisms at ambient temperatures, thereby serving as a viable alternative to conventional thermal pasteurization. This non-thermal approach preserves the organoleptic and nutritional qualities of food products by avoiding the detrimental effects associated with heat-based treatments. However, despite its efficacy in microbial control and quality retention, one notable limitation of HHP is the requirement for refrigeration of treated products, which may pose logistical and economic challenges in certain contexts16. Both prebiotic (PREB) and non-prebiotic acerola juice samples were subjected to high-temperature, short-time (HTST) and ultra-high temperature (UHT) thermal processing techniques. Concurrently, inulin was incorporated as a functional ingredient. The combined application of inulin and thermal pasteurization was found to confer protective effects on bioactive compounds present in the juice, thereby preserving their nutritional integrity and functional properties despite exposure to heat treatment17.

In meat products, the synergistic combination of inulin with other bioactive compounds has been demonstrated to significantly mitigate oxidative deterioration. For instance, the co-application of inulin and glutathione effectively prevented oxidation-induced alterations in protein secondary structures and reduced the mean particle size of pork myofibrillar proteins. This treatment exhibited superior efficacy in enhancing both the textural attributes and curing performance of heat-induced protein gels. However, it is noteworthy that the incorporation of inulin led to a reduction in gel whiteness, which may be attributable to the coloration of its oxidative byproducts18.

The coconut tree (Cocos nucifera L.) thrives in tropical regions characterized by elevated temperatures. Coconut juice, derived from the immature fruit, is recognized for its high commercial value and versatility in the production of fresh, processed, and fermented beverages. This economic potential is especially prominent in Southeast Asian countries such as India, Malaysia, Indonesia, and the Philippines, where coconut-based products constitute a significant component of both local consumption and export markets. It is also mentioned in that study that coconut sap has high levels of phenolic compounds, flavonoids, and inulin, and has a high antioxidant role19.

Given the recognized therapeutic and functional properties of L. gasseri SM 05 and L. casei subsp. casei PTCC 1608, and the lack of substantive research exploring their roles in the FT of black raspberry juice (BRJ), these two strains were selected for further investigation. While the application of natural essential oils presents a potential alternative for food preservation, several challenges—namely high cost, intense aromatic profiles, and potential toxicity—impede their widespread use in food systems. For instance, the incorporation of a 1% oregano essential oil blend in combination with modified atmosphere packaging (MAP) improved the shelf-life of fresh chicken breast meat but elicited undesirable sensory changes, particularly in flavor. Similarly, the use of oregano and thyme essential oils for microbial control on fresh produce such as lettuce and carrots led to significantly diminished organoleptic acceptability, underscoring the sensory limitations of essential oils in certain food matrices20. Reported acute oral toxicity values for tea tree and eucalyptus essential oils range from 1.9 to 2.6 mL/kg, raising concerns regarding their safety in food applications. Moreover, some essential oils have been associated with adverse reactions, such as allergic contact dermatitis20. Consequently, there is a growing interest in substituting essential oils with safer alternatives, such as natural fermented fruit juices and coconut sap. These substances offer high antioxidant activity and synergistic functional properties and, when combined with advanced HHP techniques, may be used to develop novel edible coatings with minimal risk and enhanced preservative capacity.

Recent studies have highlighted lactic acid fermentation as a cost-effective and sustainable method for enhancing the organoleptic and nutritional profiles of fresh fruit juices, while extending shelf life21. Coconut sap-derived products have also demonstrated excellent compatibility with food matrices, having been successfully incorporated into baked goods and other applications where their favorable sensory attributes are preserved. HHP processing is widely recognized for its effectiveness in retaining the integrity of phenolic compounds, making it an ideal treatment for preserving bioactive components during formulation. The innovative integration of fermented fruit juice, coconut sap, and chitosan—processed under optimized HHP conditions—can yield a highly functional coating material with promising applications in the preservation of protein-rich foods, including seafood. Accordingly, the present study aimed to evaluate the biological enhancement Rubus racemosus, a type of black raspberry (BR) fermented with Lactobacillus gasseri SM 05 and Lactobacillus casei subsp. casei PTCC 1608, and to investigate the synergistic preservation effects of combining HHP-treated coconut sap and BRJ in a chitosan-based edible coating. The formulated coatings were applied to barramundi fish fillets and assessed for oxidative stability and shelf life over a 15-day cold storage period.

sec.title: Viable cells and pH
sec.p: Figure 1 illustrates the bacterial growth dynamics and corresponding pH fluctuations over a 48-hour FT period in black raspberry juice (BRJ). The initial inoculation level of both L. gasseri and L. casei strains was approximately 6.5 log CFU/mL. During the FT process, bacterial proliferation progressed gradually, with the synbiotic treatments—LG-OEI (L. gasseri + oligofructose- enriched inulin) and LC-OEI (L. casei + oligofructose-enriched inulin)—achieving peak concentrations of 10.0 and 9.6 log CFU/mL, respectively, at 36 h. Similarly, their corresponding probiotic forms reached 9.5 and 9.2 log CFU/mL at the same time point (Fig 1a).

Following the 36-hour peak, all treatments exhibited a decline in bacterial counts, likely due to the increasingly acidic environment and limited nutrient availability. Initially, the pH was approximately 4.0, decreasing to 3.3 for LG-OEI and 3.4 for LC-OEI by the end of fermentation. The pH values for the probiotic forms similarly decreased to 3.5 and 3.6, respectively (FIG 1b), indicating progressive acidification resulting from lactic acid production.

The incorporation of these two bacterial strains into BRJ was motivated by multiple factors: Nutritional provenance: L. gasseri has been isolated from fermented camel milk, while L. casei is associated with dairy fermentation, notably in Kraft Swiss cheese. Their adaptation to nutrient-rich matrices enhances their viability in fermented juices. Functional enhancement: The combination with BRJ, rich in phenolic compounds, supports antioxidant augmentation, potentially mitigating oxidative stress in both food systems and biological tissues. Therapeutic potential: Both strains possess promising medicinal properties, including antimicrobial activity against pathogens such as Salmonella spp., which are linked to gastrointestinal disorders. Their fermentation in BRJ remains underexplored, and the production of health-promoting metabolites during FT may yield a functional beverage with significant clinical and nutritional relevance.

Supporting this approach, Li et al.. demonstrated that inoculation of Lactobacillus fermentum strains into blueberry juice at an initial level of 7.5 log CFU/mL led to substantial bacterial proliferation during FT. After 48 h, cell populations in certain subspecies exceeded 10 log CFU/mL, reflecting robust microbial adaptability and growth under acidic conditions11. After 36 h of FT), the inoculum concentration of LG-OEI (Lactobacillus gasseri combined with oligofructose-enriched inulin) remained one log CFU/mL lower than other treatments yet reached 10 log CFU/mL, suggesting robust bacterial activity within the black raspberry juice (BRJ) matrix. As illustrated in Fig. 1(b), LG-OEI exhibited the most pronounced pH decline among all samples, indicative of its heightened metabolic activity and acid production during FT. In contrast, L. casei showed the least pH reduction, reflecting comparatively lower fermentative performance under the same conditions.

Prebiotics are nondigestible compounds readily metabolized by beneficial gut microbiota, particularly lactic acid bacteria (LAB). Their fermentability contributes to host health by modulating metabolic parameters, which is especially beneficial in chronic conditions such as type 2 diabetes. Functioning as substrates for microbial growth, prebiotics—rich in dietary fiber—support the balance and proliferation of health-promoting intestinal microflora. Among these, inulin is a well-documented prebiotic with significant influence on the compositional and functional dynamics of colonic microbiota22. The incorporation of probiotics and lactic acid bacteria (LAB) into functional beverages has been widely recognized for its beneficial impact on consumer health. However, the survival and metabolic activity of these microorganisms in the highly acidic environment of fruit juices remain critical challenges. The addition of prebiotics, particularly inulin, has shown promise in enhancing probiotic viability under such conditions23. Inulin, a non-digestible carbohydrate, serves as a fermentable substrate that supports the growth of beneficial bacteria.

In fermented dairy products such as yogurt, the use of inulin has been demonstrated to improve the viability of LAB, including Bifidobacterium spp., while also enhancing product texture, shelf life, and calcium bioavailability—contributing positively to gastrointestinal health24. These outcomes underscore the role of inulin as a potent cell survival enhancer.

Furthermore, inulin has been reported to stimulate α-galactosidase activity in probiotic strains, leading to more efficient hydrolysis of oligosaccharides and simple sugars. This enzymatic activity accelerates acid production, thereby contributing to a more pronounced decline in pH during fermentation. The resulting biochemical environment not only reflects heightened microbial metabolism but also suggests improved fermentation dynamics associated with prebiotic supplementation.

caption.p: (a) Viability cell counts of synbiotic and probiotic of Lactobacillus gasseri and Lactobacillus casei in fermented black raspberry juice, and (b) changes in pH of black raspberry juice samples during fermentation for 48 h.

sec.title: Biological properties of coconut sap
sec.p: The antioxidant activity of coconut sap, evaluated using DPPH radical scavenging and reducing power assays, was recorded at 68 ± 2%, with a corresponding absorbance of 0.84 ± 0.02. Quantitative analysis revealed total phenolic content of 3200 ± 300 mg/L and flavonoid concentration of 81 ± 1 mg catechin equivalents per liter (mg CE/L). In a study conducted by Asghar et al. (2020), coconut syrup—derived through similar processing—was reported to contain 312.87 mg/100 g of phenolic compounds19. The same study identified five predominant PC in coconut sap: gallic acid, p-coumaric acid, protocatechuic acid, galangin, and caffeic acid19.

In addition to these phenolic compounds, coconut sap comprises a diverse array of polar secondary metabolites, including glycosides, steroids, triterpenoids, flavonoids, coumarins, phenols, and tannins25. These bioactive constituents contribute collectively to the biological functionality of the sap. Notably, glycosides have the capacity to form molecular complexes with sugars and other compounds, thereby establishing a robust biochemical matrix that enhances antioxidative protection.

Taken together, the findings suggest that the coconut sap sample under investigation exhibits superior bioactive potency compared to those characterized in previous studies. The elevated concentrations of phenolics and flavonoids are likely responsible for the high antioxidant capacity observed, positioning coconut sap as a promising ingredient in functional food formulations—particularly in synergistic applications with black raspberry juice (BRJ), which is similarly rich in antioxidative compounds.

sec.title: High hydrostatic pressure effect
sec.p: HHP was conducted at three pressure levels—400, 500, and 600 MPa—for durations of 2, 5, and 10 min, to determine the optimal conditions for maximizing PC content. As depicted in Fig. 2, for each pressure level, PC concentrations were highest after 10 min and lowest after 2 min of treatment. Among the pressures tested, 600 MPa yielded the greatest PC recovery, whereas 400 MPa resulted in the lowest values.

Among the two lactic acid (LA) bacterial strains employed in this study, Lactobacillus gasseri demonstrated superior fermentative performance compared to Lactobacillus casei, as evidenced by higher metabolite output and resilience under processing conditions. These findings align with previous research wherein HHP treatment of red raspberry juice led to the identification of 151 distinct phenolic compounds under similar pressure-time combinations (200, 400, and 600 MPa for 10 min)26.

The highest PC content recorded was 713 mg/L at 600 MPa for 10 min, while the lowest value was 660 mg/L at 400 MPa for 2 min. Based on these results, the pressure-time combination of 600 MPa and 10 min was deemed optimal and was used for all subsequent experimental procedures reported in Table 1.

caption.p: Effect of different pressures (megapascals) and times (minutes) of high hydrostatic processing on the content of phenolic compounds (black raspberry juice).
Effect of High hydrostatic pressure (HHP) processing on different assays.

sec.title: DPPH (2,2-diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl) assay
sec.p: Phenolic compounds act as potent reducing agents by donating electrons or hydrogen atoms, resulting in the transformation of reactive free radicals into more stable, non-radical species. This reduction mechanism effectively inhibits DPPH radicals, measurable at specific wavelengths such as 517 nm27.

As seen in Fig. 3, with increase fermentation, the probiotic strains Lactobacillus gasseri and Lactobacillus casei reached radical scavenging rates of 42% and 41.5%, respectively. The synbiotic formulations—LG-OEI (L. gasseri + oligofructose-enriched inulin) and LC-OEI (L. casei + oligofructose-enriched inulin)—exhibited slightly enhanced absorption capacities of 46% and 45%, respectively, indicating an improvement in antioxidant potential at relatively low bacterial concentrations.

By 48 h of FT, the DPPH radical scavenging activities increased markedly: 89% for L. gasseri, 88.5% for L. casei, 93% for LG-OEI, and 92% for LC-OEI. Corresponding IC₅₀ values were 131.93, 142.87, 105.00, and 116.65 mg/L, respectively, with LG-OEI displaying the highest antioxidant potency. These results surpass those reported by Li et al.11 for Lactobacillus plantarum fermented apple juice, which showed 77.45% scavenging efficiency—an increase of 36.08% compared to its unfermented counterpart26. The improved DPPH scavenging suggests enhanced release and bioavailability of polyphenolic compounds facilitated by LAB-mediated fermentation28,29. A comparative analysis reveals that the BRJ samples fermented with L. gasseri and L. casei, both probiotic and synbiotic variants, exhibited 11–15.5% greater antioxidant activity than similar studies using L. plantarum in apple juice. This underscores higher fermentation efficacy, increased polyphenol biotransformation, and greater strain compatibility within the BRJ matrix. Moreover, previous research has shown that FT using L. plantarum and other LAB enhances the utilization of polyphenolic compounds with proton-donating functionality26,30.

A distinctive advantage of the current study lies in the exceptional compatibility of the selected LAB strains with BRJ, as evidenced by a 1.9- to 2-fold increase in DPPH radical scavenging across all probiotic and synbiotic treatments at an inoculation rate of 6.5 log CFU/mL. In contrast, a 2022 study involving loquat juice fermented with L. plantarum and L. acidophilus (inoculated at 7 log CFU/mL) reported comparatively lower increases of 1.73- and 1.71-fold, respectively31.

caption.p: DPPH scavenging of black raspberry juice during fermentation by by types of synbiotic and probiotic of Lactobacillus gasseri and Lactobacillus casei.

sec.title: Antioxidant activity in a fish model system (TBARS)
sec.p: Aldehydes and ketones represent key secondary products of lipid oxidation, contributing to off-flavors in meat and fat-containing food matrices. Lipid oxidation proceeds via multiple pathways—including free radical, enzymatic, and non-enzymatic non-radical mechanisms—as described by Karimkhani et al. (2021)32. To assess oxidative stability, the antioxidant performance of BRJ samples—both alone and in combination with coconut sap—was evaluated in a fish-based preservation model over a 15-day storage period also Chitosan, a biopolymer derived from chitin, possesses notable antioxidant properties attributed to its abundant hydroxyl and amino functional groups, which facilitate the formation of intra- and intermolecular hydrogen bonds. Importantly, chitosan can also establish hydrogen bonds with phenolic compounds, thereby stabilizing and protecting these bioactive molecules from oxidative degradation. The antioxidant activity of phenolic compounds varies depending on the number and position of hydroxyl and methoxyl groups, as well as their electron-donating capacity. Enhanced molecular stability of phenolics correlates with improved antioxidative efficacy.

Moreover, when chitosan is combined with phenolic compounds, a synergistic enhancement in antioxidant potential is observed—resulting from increased electron-donating interactions and protective molecular associations. This combination is particularly effective in black raspberry juice formulations, where chitosan coatings play a critical role in preserving phenolic integrity and extending shelf life in protein-rich foods such as fish33,34. Given the high concentration of phenolic compounds in coconut sap, its incorporation into chitosan-based formulations is hypothesized to enhance antioxidant efficacy, particularly in the preservation of fish samples. To investigate this, seven experimental groups—BHA (positive control), Themal processing (TP) Juice + LG-OEI, TP Juice + LG, TP Juice + LC-OEI, TP Juice + LC, Control, and HHP Juice—were subjected to two levels of coconut sap concentration (5% and 10%) and three processing conditions (VAT: low-temperature long-time pasteurization, HHP: high-hydrostatic pressure processing, and Control: untreated).

Across the 15-day refrigerated storage period at 4 °C, Fig. 4(a) demonstrated a continuous increase in TBARS (thiobarbituric acid reactive substances) values for BR juice with BHA, indicating progressive lipid oxidation. Samples were coded based on treatment and concentration: 10HHP, 10Control, 5HHP, 5Control, 10VAT, and 5VAT. Ranking their antioxidative performance yielded the following order: 10HHP > 10Control > 5HHP > 5Control > 10VAT > 5VAT.

Excluding BHA, the TP Juice + LG-OEI group exhibited the strongest antioxidant activity, while the untreated control was least effective. Notably, in samples without added coconut sap, HHP juice showed weaker antioxidant effects on days 3 and 6 compared to TP Juice + LG-OEI and TP Juice + LC-OEI; however, its performance improved on days 9, 12, and 15, likely due to the inactivation of oxidative enzymes (e.g., polyphenol oxidase, peroxidase) through HHP processing. These enzymes, as well as thermally sensitive phenolic compounds, may be more degraded by conventional thermal methods than by HHP.

In Fig. 4(a), TBARS values in fermented BR (FBR) samples were below 7 mg MDA Eq/kg up to day 6, but rose progressively thereafter. When coconut sap was added at 5% and 10% to both fermented and unfermented BRJ, and processed via HHP, VAT, or left untreated, TBARS levels in HHP and control samples remained below 7 mg MDA Eq/kg through day 9 (Figs. 4[b]–[f]), indicating improved short-term oxidative stability. However, in Fig. 4(d), the VAT-treated samples with 5% coconut sap recorded TBARS values of 7.5 and 7 mg MDA Eq/kg for control and HHP groups, respectively, on day 9—showing VAT’s relatively greater oxidative degradation despite still acceptable values.

Figures 4(d) and 4(g) emphasize the concentration-dependent effect of coconut sap. At 10%, the TP Juice + LG sample yielded an acceptable TBARS value of 7.8 mg MDA Eq/kg on day 12, whereas TP Juice + LC slightly exceeded permissible limits at 8.1 mg MDA Eq/kg. By contrast, at 5% coconut sap, both TP Juice + LG and TP Juice + LC reached unacceptable TBARS values of 8.5 and 8.7 mg MDA Eq/kg, respectively, indicative of spoilage.

Among all tested groups, the control without coconut sap displayed the weakest antioxidative performance, reaching 10 mg MDA Eq/kg TBARS. In contrast, the strongest treatment—HHP Juice with 10% coconut sap—demonstrated variability, with TP Juice + LG-OEI, TP Juice + LC-OEI, and BHA outperforming other treatments during days 3, 6, and 9. The best-performing sample reported a TBARS value as low as 2.9 mg MDA Eq/kg. Nevertheless, BHA maintained superior antioxidant effects on days 12 and 15, highlighting that while HHP is a robust preservation method, its long-term oxidative resistance does not surpass that of synthetic antioxidants.

Previous studies have established benchmark thresholds for TBARS in evaluating the oxidative quality of fish and fishery products. TBARS values below 8 mg MDA Eq/kg are generally considered acceptable for human consumption, while values below 5 mg MDA Eq/kg denote good quality. To meet criteria for optimal freshness and minimal oxidative degradation, TBARS levels must fall below 3 mg MDA Eq/kg, indicating perfect quality35. One of the most compelling and innovative aspects of this study is the integration of coconut sap into a chitosan-based coating combined with fermented black raspberry juice (BRJ). This formulation demonstrated a significant improvement in oxidative stability of fish samples, extending their shelf life by six days compared to analogous coatings without coconut sap, as evidenced in Fig. 4a; Table 3. Notably, TBARS values for all samples—excluding the BHA control—exceeded 8 mg MDA Eq/kg, rendering them unsuitable for consumption according to established quality standards.

Relative to previous investigations, these findings are particularly noteworthy due to the development of a novel bioactive coating. For instance, Hossein et al.35 reported unacceptable TBARS levels on the 12th and 15th days of refrigerated storage in Atlantic salmon treated with a coating based on Atlantic sea cucumber extract. A key point of differentiation in the present study is the performance of the TP Juice + LG-OEI formulation—blended with 10% coconut sap and subjected to HHP—which exhibited antioxidant activity equivalent to that of BHA on day 9. This outcome underscores the potential of HHP to preserve bioactive integrity and produce a highly effective, safe coating that rivals the antioxidative efficacy of synthetic antioxidants.

Importantly, synthetic compounds such as butylated hydroxyanisole (BHA) and butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT) are widely used in food preservation due to their strong antioxidant properties. However, concerns regarding their carcinogenicity and adverse health effects have prompted increased interest in natural alternatives. The ability of biologically derived coatings to match or exceed the oxidative inhibition power of synthetic antioxidants—without associated toxicity—marks a significant advancement in food science and preservation technology.

In comparison to a 2025 study employing a chitosan (CH), fish oil (FO), and green tea extract composite coating for preserving Atlantic bonito fish, which achieved an oxidation inhibition period of 12 days, the current study offers a similarly competitive, if not superior, preservation strategy. While the previous formulation demonstrated extended shelf life and oxidative protection, the novel use of coconut sap combined with fermented black raspberry juice and chitosan—particularly when subjected to HHP—resulted in comparable antioxidative efficacy, including equivalent TBARS suppression to synthetic antioxidant BHA by day 9. These findings underscore the versatility and effectiveness of naturally derived bioactive coatings, while minimizing potential health risks associated with synthetic additives36, Compared to a previous 2025 study utilizing chitosan, fish oil, and green tea extract—which demonstrated an oxidation inhibition period of 12 days—the current formulation based on chitosan, BRJ, and coconut sap treated with HHP extended the preservation period by an additional 3 days. This enhanced protection against lipid oxidation underscores the synergistic potential of the selected ingredients and processing method.

As detailed in Table 2, the simultaneous effects of coconut sap concentration and processing techniques were evaluated on fermented BRJ samples containing oligofructose and inulin to enhance FT efficacy. The twelfth day was identified as a critical timepoint, exhibiting peak oxidation rates in fish samples treated with BRJ and coconut juice. Results indicated that the 10HHP treatment—combining 10% coconut syrup with HHP—was the most effective strategy, significantly inhibiting oxidation. In contrast, 5VAT (5% coconut extract with low-temperature long-time pasteurization) was the least effective, demonstrating inadequate protection on the twelfth day.

Across all BRJ formulations—including those subjected to HHP and TP—concentration of coconut syrup proved more influential than the choice of pasteurization method. Thermal degradation associated with VAT treatments compromised antioxidant activity, making 10VAT and 5VAT the weakest among all tested samples. Remarkably, even the unpasteurized control with 5% coconut syrup exhibited superior antioxidative performance, highlighting the destructive impact of prolonged heat exposure on phenolic integrity.

Importantly, fermented and unfermented BRJ samples containing 10% coconut syrup and processed via HHP maintained oxidative stability in fish oil up to 15 days, whereas TP-treated samples without coconut syrup showed protection for only 6 days. A gradual decline in TBARS values after day 12 may be attributed to reactions between amines and secondary oxidation products, or further oxidation leading to substrate depletion—thus reducing the formation of TBA-reactive dye complexes37,38.

These results emphasize that coconut sap—rich in inulin and dietary fiber—plays a significant protective role when paired with BRJ, which is abundant in PC. The application of coconut sap in a chitosan-based coating, combined with its bioactive preservation via HHP and BRJ fermentation, constitutes a novel approach not previously explored. This innovative strategy offers promising advancements in the formulation of natural, functional coatings for seafood preservation. A comparative study of the antioxidant capacity and vitamin content in coconut sap, sugarcane juice, and palm sugar revealed that coconut sap contains substantially higher concentrations of antioxidant-active compounds and vitamins than those found in sugarcane and date-based juices. These findings highlight the nutritional superiority of coconut sap, which, owing to its richness in inulin and dietary fiber, may exert a protective effect against oxidative deterioration in fish products—particularly when combined with BR juice, known for its abundant PC. Furthermore, appropriate thermal pasteurization techniques play a critical role in safeguarding PC in fruit juices; the greater the retention of PC, the more pronounced their antioxidative efficacy when co-applied with coconut sap in seafood preservation19.

caption.p: (a) Effect of black raspberry juice samples without coconut sap with chitosan coating on Barramundi fish oxidation (TBARS) during 15 days (b) Effect of high hydrostatic processing after adding 5% coconut sap to black raspberry juice samples (5 HHP) with chitosan coating on Barramundi fish oxidation (TBARS) during 15 days. (c) Effect of control after adding 5% coconut sap to black raspberry juice samples (5 Control) with chitosan coating on Barramundi fish oxidation (TBARS) during 15 days. (d) Effect of VAT pasteurization after adding 5% coconut sap to black raspberry juice samples (5 VAT) with chitosan coating on Barramundi fish oxidation (TBARS) during 15 days.(e) Effect of high hydrostatic processing after adding 10% coconut sap to black raspberry juice samples (10 HHP) with chitosan coating on Barramundi fish oxidation (TBARS) during 15 days. (f). Control (without cold or hot pasteurization) after adding 10% coconut sap to black raspberry juice samples (10 Control) with chitosan coating on Barramundi fish oxidation (TBARS) during 15 days. (g) Effect of VAT pasteurization after adding 10% coconut sap to black raspberry juice samples (10 VAT) with chitosan coating on Barramundi fish oxidation (TBARS) during 15 days.

Oxidation changes of fish with different groups of raspberry juice mixed with 5 and 10% coconut juice and pasteurization by HHP, VAT and without pasteurization (control) with Chitosan coating on the twelfth day.

sec.p: Critically, the difference in oxidative stability between the highest-performing sample (10% coconut juice + HHP) and the weakest fish samples lacking both coconut sap and pasteurization reached approximately 3 to 4 oxidation units by day 12. This variance is highly significant, highlighting the robust protective capacity of phenolic-rich coconut sap when processed under non-thermal HHP conditions. The magnitude of this difference underscores the pivotal role of natural synergistic formulations and processing techniques in mitigating oxidative deterioration of protein-rich foods.

caption.p: Oxidation changes of fish with different groups of raspberry juice without coconut Sap (no syrup) with Chitosan coating during 15 days.
Oxidation changes of fish with different groups of raspberry juice mixed with 10% coconut Sap and HHP pasteurization (10HHP) with Chitosan coating during 15 days.

sec.title: Experimental design
sec.p: Response Surface Methodology (RSM) utilizing a central composite design (CCD) was employed via SPSS Version 26 software to model lipid oxidation levels in preserved fish samples. The dependent variable—oxidation—was analyzed in relation to a combination factor (Concentration × Pasteurization) and a categorical Group Factor comprising seven treatment levels:
BHA (positive control); TP Juice + LG-OEI; TP Juice + LG; TP Juice + LC-OEI; TP Juice + LC; Control; HHP Juice.

The concentration factor included two levels of coconut sap (5% and 10%), while pasteurization was applied at three levels: VAT (low-temperature long-time), HHP (high-pressure processing), and no treatment (Control). Table 5 outlines the factorial structure across six black raspberry juice (BRJ) sample types. Oxidation data (expressed as TBARS values) were collected in three replicates at six timepoints: Day 0, 3, 6, 9, 12, and 15.

Here, the parameter estimates, in this regression model, turn out to be related to the effect estimates. The corresponding response surface plots are given in Fig. 5 separately for each concentration and pasteurization levels.

As illustrated in Fig. 5a, the highest level of lipid oxidation was observed in fish samples treated with six BRJ-based groups mixed with 5% coconut syrup and subjected to VAT pasteurization (5VAT). Despite increasing coconut syrup concentration to 10% in Fig. 5d (10VAT), oxidation levels remained elevated, indicating that high-temperature, long-time pasteurization may undermine the protective antioxidant capacity of phenolic-rich coconut sap. In contrast, Fig. 5e and f recorded the lowest TBARS values, demonstrating superior antioxidant performance—particularly in samples treated via HHP (10HHP).

Notably, all groups under the 10HHP condition, excluding the control, exhibited oxidation rates below 6 mg MDA Eq/kg, reinforcing the efficacy of HHP in preserving antioxidant compounds and mitigating oxidative degradation.

From a statistical modeling perspective, the response surface plots revealed non-linear interactions across treatment factors, confirming that interactions between concentration and pasteurization method are significant. As reported in Table 5, the regression analysis yielded an F-value of 137.422 with a p-value (Sig.) < 0.05, signifying that the model is statistically significant. Furthermore, the model’s R² value of 0.973 and adjusted R² of 0.965 indicate an excellent fit, explaining over 96% of the variability in oxidation response across samples.

caption.p: The experimental design and the results of secondary oxidation by three variables of combination (coconut sap* pasteurization), group, and days.

sec.title: High Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC) analysis
sec.p: As presented in Fig. 6; Table 6, a total of 13 PC were identified in BRJ following HHP. Among these, cyanidin-3-O-rutinoside exhibited the highest concentration, followed by cyanidin-3-O-glucoside, kaempferol, cinnamic acid, ellagic acid, and gallic acid—the latter being classified as a key bioactive in the sample. Ferulic acid was found in the lowest quantity. The total phenolic content recorded was 70.35 mg/100 g, confirming the preservation of a substantial polyphenol profile through HHP.

These findings align closely with those of previous studies on similar raspberry varieties. For instance, cyanidin derivatives—including cyanidin-3-O-glucoside, cyanidin-3-O-xylosyl-rutinoside, and cyanidin-3-O-rutinoside—have consistently been reported as predominant anthocyanins contributing to the strong antioxidant capacity of black raspberries. The presence of both flavonoids (e.g., kaempferol) and hydroxybenzoic acids (e.g., gallic acid) suggests a rich matrix of antioxidant mechanisms, supporting the juice’s functional efficacy in food preservation and health-promoting applications39,40. According to the 2024 study by Karimkhani et al., the phenolic compound profile in fermented Rubus dolichocarpus juice was ranked in the following order based on concentration:
Ellagic acid > Cyanidin-3-glucoside > Gallic acid > Ferulic acid > Caffeic acid > Quercetin > Kaempferol > p-Coumaric acid > Myricetin-3-glucoside > Chlorogenic acid41.

This hierarchy reflects the dominance of ellagitannins and anthocyanins—particularly ellagic acid and cyanidin derivatives—which are known for their potent antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. The presence of flavonols like quercetin and kaempferol further enhances the bioactivity of the juice, while hydroxycinnamic acids such as ferulic and caffeic acids contribute to its radical-scavenging capacity.

caption.p: The chromatogram (HPLC analysis) of the polyphenol content of high hydrostatic pressure black raspberry juice: 1- Cinnamic acid 2- Gallic acid 3- Cyanidin 3-O-rutinoside 4- Cyanidin 3-O-glucoside 5- Kaempferol 6- Epigallocatechin gallate 7- Caffeic acid 8- Syringic acid 9- Rutin trihydrate 10- Ellagic acid 11- p-Coumaric acid 12- Ferulic acid 13- Quercetin.
The content of phenolic compounds in black raspberry juice under high hydrostatic pressure.

sec.title: Anti-inflammatory activity (AI)
sec.p: Eicosanoids—including leukotrienes, prostaglandins, prostacyclins, thromboxanes, isoprostanes, and cytochrome P450-derived oxidative metabolites—are bioactive lipids derived from arachidonic acid (AA) that play central roles in inflammation and oxidative stress. Among these, prostaglandins are particularly prominent, synthesized via cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes in various cell types. They contribute to inflammatory cascades by promoting vasodilation, fever, bronchoconstriction, and mucus hypersecretion42. Bioactive compounds present in black raspberry (BR) have demonstrated regulatory effects on key inflammatory mediators, including cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2), interleukins (ILs), and nuclear factor-kappa B (NF-κB)—suggesting their potential to modulate inflammatory pathways and reduce oxidative damage43.

In parallel, LAB such as Lactiplantibacillus plantarum have been shown to possess notable anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, antigenotoxic, and immunomodulatory properties. According to Garcia-Gonzalez et al., food-derived L. plantarum strains exhibit strong gastrointestinal adhesion and compatibility, enhancing their functional efficacy in host systems44. These strains have been associated with modulation of gut microbiota, suppression of pro-inflammatory cytokines, and protection against genotoxic agents—making them promising candidates for therapeutic and functional food applications.

In the present study, the anti-inflammatory (AI) potential of fermented BRJ was assessed through its inhibitory activity against 5-lipoxygenase (5-LOX), a key enzyme involved in the biosynthesis of pro-inflammatory eicosanoids. The AI activity was evaluated across four bacterial treatments: LG-OEI , L. gasseri, LC-OEI and L. casei. As shown in Fig. 7, the AI activities at the end of the fermentation period reached 69%, 68%, 67%, and 66.5%, respectively, indicating that the synbiotic formulation LG-OEI exhibited the highest inhibitory effect.

These findings are consistent with those reported by Hashemi et al. (2021), who investigated the AI activity of fermented peach juice inoculated with Lactobacillus acidophilus and Lactobacillus fermentum. In their study, AI activity increased significantly from a baseline of 6.47–38.50% and 32.77% for L. acidophilus and L. fermentum, respectively45. The higher AI values observed in the current BRJ-based formulations suggest enhanced bioactivity, likely due to the synergistic effects of phenolic compounds in BRJ and the metabolic contributions of the selected LAB strains46. Additionally, polyphenols, abundant in fermented fruit matrices such as black raspberry juice (BRJ), exhibit potent antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. These compounds improve gut barrier integrity and reduce systemic inflammation by modulating oxidative stress and inflammatory signaling pathways47. A particularly noteworthy metabolite is gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), a non-protein amino acid synthesized by select LAB strains—most notably Levilactobacillus brevis—via the glutamate decarboxylase (GAD) pathway. GABA has been associated with a range of health benefits, including anti-inflammatory, antihypertensive, and neuroprotective effects, and its production during fermentation enhances the functional value of probiotic beverages. The presence of GABA-producing LAB in the current study likely contributes to the observed AI activity, complementing the effects of polyphenols and bacteriocins48. Taken together, the high PCs of BRJ, the bacteriocin production by LAB, and the biosynthesis of GABA form a triad of bioactive mechanisms that underpin the anti-inflammatory efficacy of the fermented formulations investigated in this research.

caption.p: Anti-inflammatory activity (%) of black raspberry juice during fermentation by types of synbiotic and probiotic of Lactobacillus gasseri and Lactobacillus casei.

sec.title: Total phenolic content (TPC)
sec.p: In this study, Fig. 8 shows that fermentation with L. gasseri and L. casei, especially in synbiotic formulations (LG-OEI and LC-OEI), significantly enhanced the TPC of BRJ—with increases ranging from 52.7 to 63.7%. This is notably higher than the phenolic enrichment reported by Li et al.., where fermentation of blueberry juice with L. plantarum LSJ-TY-HYB-T9 and L. fermentum LSJ-TY-HYB-H33 led to TPC increases of 41.8% and 57.9%, respectively. These elevated phenolic levels in your BRJ samples suggest a more efficient biotransformation of polyphenols, possibly due to better substrate compatibility or enhanced enzymatic activity of the selected LAB strains. The fact that LG-OEI outperformed all others also reinforces the synergistic role of inulin in boosting fermentation efficacy and polyphenol release11.

caption.p: Total phenolic content (mg/L) of black raspberry juice during fermentation by types of synbiotic and probiotic of Lactobacillus gasseri and Lactobacillus casei.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: BRJ formulations containing synbiotic lactic acid bacteria exhibited superior biological activity and antioxidant capacity compared to those with probiotic bacteria alone. Among the strains tested, L. gasseri produced a higher concentration of metabolites than Lactobacillus casei, contributing to enhanced antioxidant properties. In addition, chitosan-based coatings incorporating synbiotic LAB, 10% coconut sap, and subjected to HHPdemonstrated significantly greater inhibition of fish lipid oxidation during 15 days of cold storage. The antioxidative mechanism attributed to coconut sap stems from its rich inulin and dietary fiber content, which synergistically complement the phenolic compounds in BRJ. These findings highlight the potential of coconut sap as a functional ingredient in oxidation-sensitive matrices. Future research may focus on the development of advanced encapsulation technologies using chitosan or naturally derived gums with antioxidant properties to enhance the delivery, stability, and bioefficacy of coconut-derived phenolics in diverse food systems. Given the rising need for natural preservatives, coconut sap phenolics represent a promising solution for improving the oxidative stability of high-risk foods such as snacks, surimi, and hamburgers—particularly in formulations that demand clean-label alternatives to synthetic antioxidants.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: L. gasseri SM 0549 and L. casei Subsp. casei PTCC 1608 (ATCC 39392) were purchased from the Institute of Industrial Fungi and Bacteria of Iran. Other laboratory chemicals were obtained from Sigma Aldrich Chemical Co. (St. Louis, USA).

sec.title: Preparation and fermentation of black raspberry juice
sec.p: BRJ was prepared according to the literature11 with slight modifications. Raspberry (Rubus racemosus) samples were collected in accordance with relevant national and international ethical and regulatory frameworks, including the IUCN policy statement concerning studies involving potentially endangered species. As R. racemosus is not classified as a protected or conserved species, official permission for sample collection and identification of growth regions was obtained from the Agricultural Office of Gilan Province. Only a minimal quantity necessary for experimentation was harvested to ensure sustainability and ecological integrity. The collected berries were thoroughly washed with sterile water, manually juiced, and subsequently homogenized. The juice was filtered using eight layers of sterilized gauze to ensure removal of particulate matter and microbial contaminants. To optimize fermentation conditions and maintain microbial viability, the pH of the juice was adjusted to approximately 4.0 using 1 M sodium carbonate (Na₂CO₃)41. To optimize fermentation conditions, the total soluble solids (TSS) of BRJ were adjusted to 15 °Brix, followed by thermal pasteurization at 80 °C for 5 min to ensure microbial safety and preserve phenolic integrity. Subsequently, the pasteurized juice was inoculated with 1% (v/v) of probiotic cultures—Lactobacillus gasseri SM05 and Lactobacillus casei subsp. casei—to enhance its biological activity. The lactic acid bacteria were pre-cultured to ensure high cell viability. Strains were first incubated in De Man, Rogosa, and Sharpe (MRS) agar for 24 h at 30 °C to establish colonies. A specific colony amount was then transferred into MRS broth and cultivated for biomass expansion. A total of 20 mL of active bacterial suspension was prepared and used as the inoculum source for the fermentation stage50. Synbiotic Formulation and Inoculation Protocol Following initial cultivation, the lactic acid bacteria cultures were centrifuged at 4000 rpm for 10 min to separate the biomass. The resulting pellet was washed twice with sterile saline solution to remove residual medium components and enhance purity. A total volume of 150 mL of purified bacterial suspension was subsequently incorporated into the BRJ.

For synbiotic preparation, the pretreated lactic acid bacteria were added to BRJ supplemented with 75 g/L of Oligofructose-Enriched Inulin (OEI). This prebiotic component was selected to improve bacterial viability and fermentation efficiency, thereby enhancing the functional and biological properties of the final beverage22. A stock solution of lactic acid bacteria (Lactobacillus gasseri and Lactobacillus casei) was prepared at a concentration of 1.5 × 10⁸ CFU/mL, corresponding to an optical density measurement of OD600 using a spectrophotometer. To achieve a target inoculation level of 6.5 log CFU/mL, 1 mL of the stock solution was diluted with 13.5 mL of sterile distilled water, and the resulting mixture was introduced into the pasteurized fruit juice under aseptic conditions.

The inoculatedBRJ samples were incubated in dark conditions at 37 °C for 48 h to facilitate fermentation. Microbial growth and biochemical changes were monitored at predetermined intervals: 0, 6, 12, 24, 36, and 48 h. At each time point, relevant assays were conducted to assess microbial viability, antioxidant activity, phenolic compound evolution, and anti-inflammatory properties—allowing for dynamic evaluation of fermentation performance.

sec.title: Determination of viable cells
sec.p: Viable cell counts were determined using the serial dilution technique with sterile peptone water as the diluent, prepared to a final dilution of 10⁻⁶. From each dilution level, 0.1 mL aliquots were aseptically plated onto De Man, Rogosa, and Sharpe (MRS) agar using the spread plate method, performed in triplicate to ensure accuracy and reproducibility.

The plates were incubated at 30 °C for 48 h, allowing for optimal growth of lactic acid bacteria. Following incubation, plates exhibiting 30–300 colonies were selected for enumeration. The results were expressed as colony-forming units (CFU) per mL of sample solution, calculated according to the standard microbial quantification protocol51.

sec.title: pH measurement
sec.p: The pH of the samples was determined with a pH meter (WTW Bench PH meter 7110, Germany).

sec.title: Processing of coconut Sap
sec.p: Coconut palm sap was sourced from Cocos nucifera L. and processed using vacuum rotary evaporation at temperatures below 50 °C to concentrate the sap to 60 °Brix19. Following concentration, the sap was analyzed for its phenolic and flavonoid content, as well as its antioxidant capacity using standard assays.

Subsequently, the concentrated coconut sap was incorporated into BRJ formulations at 5% and 10% (v/v) levels. These enriched BRJ samples were applied as coating treatments to barramundi fish (Lates calcarifer) specimens harvested from the Persian Gulf, and their antioxidant activity was monitored over a 15-day refrigerated storage period.

sec.title: High hydrostatic pressure effects
sec.p: BRJ samples were processed using a high-pressure system manufactured by Baotou Kefa Co. (Inner Mongolia, China), as described in references52,53 The processing chamber featured an internal diameter and height of 20 cm, with a total capacity of 6.2 L and an operational pressure range of 0.1–600 MPa. Water maintained at 21 ± 1 °C served as the pressure transmission fluid. The internal fluid temperature increased by approximately 2.5 ± 0.5 °C per 100 MPa of applied pressure. Pressure within the chamber reached the desired target (400, 500, or 600 MPa) in 1.5 min, followed by a controlled release phase lasting 10–15 s. BRJ samples were treated at three pressure levels (400, 500, and 600 MPa) for 2, 5, and 10 min, respectively, at room temperature to assess PC retention and bioactivity. Based on comparative analysis, the treatment condition of 600 MPa for 10 min yielded the highest phenolic content, and this optimized HPP setting was selected for all subsequent experiments involving fermented BRJ—alone or combined with coconut sap—to ensure maximal bioactive retention and functional performance.

sec.title: DPPH free radical scavenging assay
sec.p: DPPH radical scavenging activity was evaluated based on Karimkhani et al.‘s method54. About 4 mL of the mixture of BRJ with LA bacteria was added to 1 mL of a methanolic solution of DPPH radicals (0.5 mM). The mixture was then incubated at 25 °C for 30 min. Finally, the absorbance was recorded at 517 nm. The scavenging ability was quantified according to the literature55.

sec.title: Preparation of coating for fish preservation
sec.p: To formulate a uniform edible coating, a 2% (w/v) chitosan solution was prepared by dissolving chitosan in 1% (v/v) acetic acid, followed by continuous stirring for 3 h at 25 °C to ensure complete solubilization. Subsequently, glycerol was incorporated as a plasticizer at a concentration of 0.7 mL/g of chitosan, and the mixture was stirred for an additional 10 min to achieve homogeneity. The resulting solution was filtered through standard filter paper to remove insoluble particles. The base chitosan solution was enriched with various formulations, including:
Fermented and non-fermented black raspberry juice (BRJ) at a concentration of 1000 mg/L.
Combinations of fermented and non-fermented BRJ with 5% and 10% coconut sap, designed to evaluate synergistic antioxidant and preservative effects.

Fresh barramundi fish fillets were immersed in the coating solutions using a two-step dipping procedure, with each immersion lasting 4 min. Post-application, the coated fillets were dried under a biological laminar flow hood to ensure uniform film formation. Samples were then packaged in sterilized low-density polyethylene (LDPE) zip-lock bags and stored under refrigerated conditions (4 °C) for a period of 15 days.

To monitor oxidative stability, all treated fish samples were analyzed at six time intervals: Day 0, 3, 6, 9, 12, and 15, using standardized lipid oxidation assays (e.g., TBARS determination) and all experiments were performed in triplicate56.

sec.title: Antioxidant activity in a fish model system (TBARS)
sec.p: Fresh Persian Gulf barramundi fillets were procured from the local market. A total of 400 g of fish was combined with 100 mL of distilled water in sterilized Mason jars. Various coating formulations—including chitosan-based solutions enriched with either synbiotic or probiotic lactic acid bacteria, as well as samples subjected to HHP—were immediately added. BHA served as the positive control. The mixtures were gently stirred in a water bath at 80 °C for 5 min, then cooked for 45 min, cooled, and sealed in sterilized LDPE zip-lock bags for refrigerated storage at 4 °C over a period of 15 days.
TBARS Assay for Lipid Oxidation: To evaluate oxidative degradation, the TBARS assay was conducted at 0, 3, 6, 9, 12, and 15 days of storage.

sec.title: Extraction
sec.p: A 1 g sample of fish was homogenized with 2.5 mL of trichloroacetic acid (TCA) and vigorously stirred for 2 min. 2.5 mL of 2-thiobarbituric acid (TBA, 0.02 M) was added and mixed thoroughly. The mixture was centrifuged at 3000 × g for 10 min. Supernatants were filtered using Whatman No. 3 filter paper.
Filtrates were heated at 95 °C for 40 min in a water bath, then cooled to room temperature.

A standard curve was generated using 1,1,3,3-tetramethoxypropane (a malondialdehyde [MDA] precursor). Absorbance was measured at 532 nm using a UV–Vis spectrophotometer. TBARS values were expressed as mg MDA equivalents per kg of sample57.

sec.title: HPLC analysis
sec.p: Identification of major phenolic compounds was performed using high-performance ternary gradient liquid chromatography (HPLC) system Azura model from Knauer Co. made in Germany, equipped with P6.1 L pump and MWD 2.1 UV detector.

To quantify phenolic constituents in BRJ, 2 g of sample was transferred into a 10 mL volumetric flask, and the volume was adjusted with methanol. The mixture was subjected to ultrasonic homogenization for 20 min at room temperature to ensure complete solubilization of bioactives. The resulting extract was then centrifuged at 5000 rpm for 15 min, and the clear supernatant was filtered through a 0.45 μm membrane filter to remove particulates. Filtered samples were analyzed using a HPLC system equipped with a Zorbax Extend-C18 column (5 μm, 250 × 4.6 mm; Agilent Technologies). The following conditions were applied: Mobile phase: Acetonitrile; Buffer: 0.5% (v/v) acetic acid in water; Injection volume: 20 µL; Gradient program: Initial acetonitrile concentration of 10%, linearly increased to 100% over 35 min; Flow rate: 1.0 mL/min; Detection wavelength: 280 nm using diode-array detection (DAD). Peak identification was performed by comparing retention times and UV spectra with known standards for key phenolic compounds54.

sec.title: Anti-Inflammatory (AI) activity
sec.p: The AI evaluation was performed against the 5-LOX enzyme using Villarreal-Soto et al.58. A mixture of 150 µL of 100 mM phosphate buffer, 20 µL of BRJ, 60 µL of linoleic acid (3.5 mmol/L), and 20 µL of 5-LOX (Soybean 500 U) was incubated at 25 °C for 10 min in the spectrophotometer and the absorbance was measured at 234 nm. The AI activity was defined as the percentage of IH of the 5-LOX enzyme.

sec.title: Total phenolic content (TPC)
sec.p: Specifically, 0.2 mL of BRJ with proper dilution was mixed with 1.5 mL of 10-fold-diluted Folin-Ciocalteu reagent and 1.5 mL of 7.5% (w/v) sodium carbonate and having been kept at room temperature in the dark for 40 min, the absorbance was recorded at 765 nm using a UV-Vis spectrophotometer. The TPC was standardized against gallic acid and expressed as mg gallic acid equivalents/L11.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: All the experiments were performed in triplicate and the findings were presented as the mean ± standard deviation (SD). SAS software (version 9.4) was used to compare the data. All data were analyzed as factorial arrangement based on the completely random design with three replications. The repeated measure one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was used to compare the difference of means in each time of analysis. Duncan post hoc test was used to compare the means in the different treatments. A p-value ≤ 0.05 was considered significantly different. In all Figs., different capital letters show a significant difference (p-value ≤ 0.05). The investigated factors are type of bacteria (LG, LC, LG-OEI, LC-OEI) and time (0, 6, 12, 24, 36, 48 h).
